case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. heirs and legal representatives of Amarchand N. Shroff

anchor.surface_text: s, 24B of the Income-tax Act in an Income-tax Reference. The question referred was answered in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax who is the appellant in these appeals, the respondents being the heirs and legal representatives of one Amarchand N. Shroff, deceased.

issues.text: whether the income which was received subsequent to the previous year in which Amarchand died is liable to be assessed to income-tax under s. 24B as his income in the hands of his heirs and legal representatives

anchor.surface_text: Income-tax is exigible in reference to a persons total income of the previous year. The question before us is whether the income which was received subsequent to the previous year in which Amarchand died is liable to be assessed to income-tax under s. 24B as his income in the hands of his heirs and legal representatives.

arguments.claim: Words 'if he had not died' interpreted in Allen v. Trehearne

anchor.surface_text: See Allen v. Trehearne  1938  22 Tax. Cas. 15, where the words if he had no died were interpreted.

arguments.claim: s.24B does not authorise tax on receipts by legal reps in assessment years succeeding previous year of death

anchor.surface_text: Section 24B does no authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died.

arguments.claim: Legal fiction in s.24B extends deceased's personality only for previous year of death

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year.

arguments.claim: Legal fictions limited to purpose created (Bengal Immunity)

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by this Court in Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bihar , legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should no be extended beyond that legitimate field.

arguments.claim: Assessee ordinarily living person; legal personality ceases on death

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the accounts were kept on cash basis. The assessee under the Act has ordinarily to be a living person and cannot be a dead person because his legal personality ceases on his death.

arguments.claim: No assessment possible after death apart from s.24B (Ellis Reid); fiction cannot extend beyond purpose

anchor.surface_text: The correct position is that apart from s. 24B no assessment can be made in respect of the income of a person after his death. See Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 5 I.T.C. 100.

arguments.claim: Reliance on Alfred, Kamdar, Usharani not applicable as assessee alive or receipt in previous year

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contention counsel for the Commissioner of Income-tax relied upon the scheme of the Act as given in Additional Income-tax Officer v. E. Alfred 1962 44 I.T.R. 442, 445. There is nothing said in that case which supports the contention raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax. Reliance was next placed on certain observations in a judgment of the Bombay High Court in re B. M. Kamdar 1946 14 I.T.R. 10. Those observations also are of no assistance... In that case also the amount was received by the widow in the previous year and it was earned by the deceased during the previous year.

holdings.text: But this interpretation is number in accord with the language used in s. 24B. All the sub-sections have to be read together.

anchor.surface_text: According to the submission of companynsel for the Commissioner of Income-tax the words of sub-s.  1  or any tax which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had number died mean that irrespective of the date of receipt of income receivable by a person, if the income is received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death, they are liable for payment of the tax just as the deceased would have been liable when the income was received had he been living. But this interpretation is number in accord with the language used in s. 24B. All the sub-sections have to be read together.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's broad reading of s.24B(1) rejected; requires harmonious reading of all sub-sections limiting to previous year income.

holdings.text: The second part or the words above quoted when read with sub-ss.  2  and  3  show that they are confined to cases therein mentioned. They show that those words also have to be restricted to the income received by the deceased person before his death and to the income received after his death by his heirs and legal representatives but in the previous year.

anchor.surface_text: The second part or the words above quoted when read with sub-ss.  2  and  3  show that they are confined to cases therein mentioned. They show that those words also have to be restricted to the income received by the deceased person before his death and to the income received after his death by his heirs and legal representatives but in the previous year and which had been assessed but would have been assessed as income received by him if death had number taken place. See Allen v. Trehearne  1938  22 Tax. Cas. 15, where the words if he had number died were interpreted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words in s.24B(1) 'if he had not died' confined by sub-ss.(2) and (3) to income in previous year of death.

holdings.text: Section 24B does number authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died.

anchor.surface_text: Section 24B does number authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died. Income-tax is exigible in reference to a persons total income of the previous year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24B liability does not extend beyond previous year of death; tax based on previous year's total income.

holdings.text: By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the companyrse of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year. The section was enacted by the Legislature to bring to tax, after his death, income received during his lifetime, and fill up the lacuna which was pointed out by the High Court in Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 5 I.T.C. 100.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory fiction extends deceased's personality only through previous year of death for assessment purposes.

holdings.text: legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should number be extended beyond that legitimate field.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the legal representatives have, by fiction of law, become assessees as provided in that section but that fiction cannot be extended beyond the object for which it was enacted. As was observed by this Court in Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bihar , legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should number be extended beyond that legitimate field.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Bengal Immunity: s.24B fiction cannot extend beyond taxing previous year income.

holdings.text: In the present case the amounts which are sought to be taxed and which have been held number be liable to tax are those which were number received in the previous year and are therefore number liable to tax in the several years of assessment. It cannot be said that they were income which may be deemed by fiction to have been received by the dead person.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the fiction is limited to the cases provided in the three sub-sections of s. 24B and cannot be extended further than the liability for the income received in the previous year. In the present case the amounts which are sought to be taxed and which have been held number be liable to tax are those which were number received in the previous year and are therefore number liable to tax in the several years of assessment. It cannot be said that they were income which may be deemed by fiction to have been received by the dead person and therefore they are number liable to be taxed as income of the deceased Amarchand and are number liable to be taxed in the hands of the heirs and legal representatives who cannot be deemed to be assessees for the purpose of assessment in regard to those years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts applied: receipts post previous year not taxable under s.24B fiction.

holdings.text: In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court's negative answer to referred question based on s.24B interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the companyrse of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year. The section was enacted by the Legislature to bring to tax, after his death, income received during his lifetime, and fill up the lacuna which was pointed out by the High Court in Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 5 I.T.C. 100.
In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.
In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

edges.explanation: Directly discusses 'the amounts which are sought to be taxed' matching the specific sums listed in the issue and holds they are not liable.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the fiction is limited to the cases provided in the three sub-sections of s. 24B and cannot be extended further than the liability for the income received in the previous year. In the present case the amounts which are sought to be taxed and which have been held number be liable to tax are those which were number received in the previous year and are therefore number liable to tax in the several years of assessment. It cannot be said that they were income which may be deemed by fiction to have been received by the dead person and therefore they are number liable to be taxed as income of the deceased Amarchand and are number liable to be taxed in the hands of the heirs and legal representatives who cannot be deemed to be assessees for the purpose of assessment in regard to those years.
In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.
